articles.headline: As Stress Drives Off Drone Operators, Air Force Must Cut Flights
articles.snippet: Long hours and the psychological toll of the work have forced the Pentagon to abandon its goal of increasing the flights and to instead reduce the number.
articles.abstract: Long hours and the psychological toll of the work have forced the Pentagon to abandon its goal of increasing the flights and to instead reduce the number.
articles.lead_paragraph: CREECH AIR FORCE BASE, Nev. — After a decade of waging long-distance war through their video screens, America’s drone operators are burning out, and the Air Force is being forced to cut back on the flights even as military and intelligence officials are demanding more of them over intensifying combat zones in Iraq, Syria and Yemen.
articles.byline: By Christopher Drew and Dave Philipps

articles.headline: Doing More, Not Less, to Save Retirees From Financial Ruin
articles.snippet: The United States may need to enhance Social Security rather than curb it and require employers to take more responsibility for employees’ retirement savings.
articles.abstract: The United States may need to enhance Social Security rather than curb it and require employers to take more responsibility for employees’ retirement savings.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just over 10 years ago, researchers at the University of Michigan added three questions to their Health and Retirement Study, a biennial survey of Americans over 50:

articles.headline: Generic A.D.H.D. Drug, Not Equivalent to the Brand, Is in Use Anyway
articles.snippet: The F.D.A. says that two generic versions of Concerta, an extended-release form of Ritalin for A.D.H.D., don’t measure up to the brand drug. But both are still on the market.
articles.abstract: The F.D.A. says that two generic versions of Concerta, an extended-release form of Ritalin for A.D.H.D., don’t measure up to the brand drug. But both are still on the market.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Dr. Louis Kraus, a chief of child psychiatry at a hospital in Chicago, writes prescriptions for patients who have attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder, he often chooses Concerta, an extended-release form of the drug Ritalin that gives patients relief from their symptoms for as long as 12 hours.

articles.headline: As Fed Edges Toward Rate Increases, Investors Turn Cautious
articles.snippet: Fed officials have emphasized that they expect rate increases to disrupt financial markets, increasing volatility after a long period of tranquility.
articles.abstract: Fed officials have emphasized that they expect rate increases to disrupt financial markets, increasing volatility after a long period of tranquility.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — This is not the moment the Federal Reserve will start to raise interest rates. But that day is coming, and investors are getting nervous.

articles.headline: Upsides for Steel Industry in a Russian Downturn, Despite Sanctions
articles.snippet: At Severstal and other companies in industries like steel and chemicals, workers and investors are benefiting from a weak ruble and strong dollar.
articles.abstract: At Severstal and other companies in industries like steel and chemicals, workers and investors are benefiting from a weak ruble and strong dollar.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHEREPOVETS, Russia — Burly steel workers in this gritty industrial town have their choice of free services at the company spa in a leafy park down the road from the factory.

articles.headline: Bravado and High Returns From Italian Fund Manager
articles.snippet: Investment returns match the bravado of Davide Serra, a London-based Italian hedge fund manager, who believes quantitative easing will continue.
articles.abstract: Investment returns match the bravado of Davide Serra, a London-based Italian hedge fund manager, who believes quantitative easing will continue.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — “Never, ever marry an American woman. That’s the advice I give my friends.”

articles.headline: Pope’s Views on Climate Change Add Pressure to Catholic Candidates
articles.snippet: A Florida archbishop will press the pope’s climate change message in the hope that it will resonate in particular with Marco Rubio and Jeb Bush.
articles.abstract: A Florida archbishop will press the pope’s climate change message in the hope that it will resonate in particular with Marco Rubio and Jeb Bush.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the steamy hurricane season descends on Miami, the city’s Roman Catholic archbishop, Thomas G. Wenski, is planning a summer of sermons, homilies and press events designed to highlight the threat that a warming planet, rising sea levels and more extreme storms pose to his community’s poorest and most vulnerable.

articles.headline: Greek Exit Would Shake, but Most Likely Not Shatter, Eurozone
articles.snippet: Many analysts believe that changes in the European financial system could contain the fallout if Greece defaults on its debt at the end of the month.
articles.abstract: Many analysts believe that changes in the European financial system could contain the fallout if Greece defaults on its debt at the end of the month.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is the current doomsday scenario for Europe.

articles.headline: G.O.P. Is Wary About Winning on Health Law
articles.snippet: If the Supreme Court upends President Obama’s health care law, Republicans in Congress would face a complicated challenge to fashion an alternative.
articles.abstract: If the Supreme Court upends President Obama’s health care law, Republicans in Congress would face a complicated challenge to fashion an alternative.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Republicans who have been hoping that the Supreme Court will upend President Obama’s health care law are now confronting an urgent and uncomfortable question: What if they win?

articles.headline: Industry’s Growth Leads to Leftover Embryos, and Painful Choices
articles.snippet: The subject poses profound questions about the beginning of life, the definition of family and the advances opening new reproductive possibilities.
articles.abstract: The subject poses profound questions about the beginning of life, the definition of family and the advances opening new reproductive possibilities.
articles.lead_paragraph: After years of infertility, Angel and Jeff Watts found a young egg donor to help them have a baby. They fertilized her eggs with Mr. Watts’s sperm and got 10 good embryos. Four of those embryos were transferred to Ms. Watts’s womb, resulting in two sets of twins — Alexander and Shelby, now 4 years old, and Angelina and Charles, not yet 2.

articles.headline: Export-Import Bank Divides Once-Supportive Republicans
articles.snippet: Many congressional leaders are siding with Tea Party conservatives against the 81-year-old bank, in the party’s latest debate over government’s role in the economy.
articles.abstract: Many congressional leaders are siding with Tea Party conservatives against the 81-year-old bank, in the party’s latest debate over government’s role in the economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: GREENVILLE, S.C. — South Carolinians know something about civil wars, but the latest one within the Republican Party over the federal Export-Import Bank has a couple of the state’s Republican brothers in Congress battling each other, reflecting the national party’s deepening divide over the role of government in the economy.

articles.headline: Podcasting Blossoms, but in Slow Motion
articles.snippet: Podcasts — not a flash in the pan but not an instant success, either — are gradually picking up steam.
articles.abstract: Podcasts — not a flash in the pan but not an instant success, either — are gradually picking up steam.
articles.lead_paragraph: Is podcasting in the middle of a long boom or a short bubble? The future of radio, a medium already being buffeted by streaming music, may be riding on the answer.

articles.headline: California Says Uber Driver Is Employee, Not a Contractor
articles.snippet: The ride-hailing company has long positioned itself as a “logistics company” and says its drivers are contractors, not employees.
articles.abstract: The ride-hailing company has long positioned itself as a “logistics company” and says its drivers are contractors, not employees.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a ruling that fuels a long-simmering debate over some of Silicon Valley’s fastest-growing technology companies and the work they are creating, the California Labor Commissioner’s Office said that a driver for the ride-hailing service Uber should be classified as an employee, not an independent contractor.
articles.byline: By Mike Isaac and Natasha Singer
